docs.title: plasma_volume
docs.text:
• units: m^3

  • tags: equilibrium, geometry, volume

The plasma volume represents the total three-dimensional space occupied by the plasma in a fusion device. It is calculated as the volume enclosed by the last closed flux surface (LCFS) in both tokamaks and stellarators.

The plasma volume is mathematically defined as the triple integral over the plasma region:

\(V = \iiint_{\Omega} dV\)

where \(\Omega\) represents the domain enclosed by the last closed flux surface.

In axisymmetric configurations (tokamaks), the plasma volume can be calculated using the poloidal cross-section:

\(V = 2\pi \iint_A R dR dZ\)

where \(R\) is the major radius coordinate, \(Z\) is the vertical coordinate, and \(A\) is the area of the plasma cross-section in the poloidal plane.

In stellarators and other non-axisymmetric configurations, the volume calculation must account for the three-dimensional nature of the flux surfaces:

\(V = \iiint_{\Omega} dR d\phi dZ\)

where \(\phi\) is the toroidal angle.

The plasma volume is a fundamental parameter used in many fusion-related calculations, including:

  • Energy and particle confinement time calculations
  • Plasma density calculations
  • Average pressure and beta calculations
  • Fusion power density estimates

The sign convention for volume is always positive.
